data.title: Walt Whitman Papers in the Charles E. Feinberg Collection
data.meta_description: A timeline from Walt Whitman’s publication of the first edition of his masterpiece Leaves of Grass in July 1855 through two subsequent editions and his first sighting of Abraham Lincoln as the president-elect passed through New York on his way to his March 1861 inauguration in Washington, shortly before the start of the American Civil War.
data.text:
The 95-page first edition of Leaves of Grass was announced for sale in Brooklyn and New York, printed by Rome Brothers in Brooklyn and distributed by Fowler & Wells (Lorenzo and Orson S. Fowler and Samuel R. Wells). Though no author was listed on the title page, the book was copyrighted by Walter Whitman and featured Whitman’s “carpenter” portrait as a frontispiece. The preface declared America itself to be the greatest poem.

Ralph Waldo Emerson wrote a famous letter to Whitman praising Leaves of Grass as a breakthrough work in American literature. The letter was later published in the New York Daily Tribune (in October), and used for promotional purposes by Whitman in the second edition in 1856.

Leaves of Grass received several reviews in the periodical press, including ones written anonymously by Whitman, as well by Edward Everett Hall in the North American Review and Fanny Fern in the New York Ledger.

Worked for the Brooklyn Daily Times. Sought to obtain plates for Leaves of Grass from Fowler & Wells, with the hope of converting his book of poetry to a larger edition with a new publisher. Experienced a period of great poetic creativity, writing nearly seventy new poems.

Frequented Pfaff’s tavern, a Manhattan gathering spot popular with bohemian actors, editors, musicians, and writers, located in a cellar on lower Broadway near Bleeker Street. Befriended Pffaf’s regular Henry Clapp, editor of the Saturday Press. Experienced a difficult period of unemployment.

“A Child’s Reminiscence” (later retitled “Out of the Cradle Endlessly Rocking”) published on the front page of the holiday issue of Clapp’s Saturday Press.

Arrived in Boston to oversee production of an expanded edition of Leaves of Grass to be published and distributed by Thayer and Eldridge.

Resisted Emerson’s suggestion that the new Enfans d’Adam cluster of poems, celebrating love between women and men, should be edited out of the new edition due to erotic content. Attended Boston-based lectures, services, and meetings, including sessions held by anti-slavery advocates. Befriended by editor, writer, and abolitionist William Douglas O’Connor (1832-1889), who later became a close friend and champion of Whitman in Washington, D.C.

Third edition of Leaves of Grass is electrotyped to high aesthetic standard and published. The new, expanded and carefully designed, 1860 version of the book was clothbound (in a variety of colors--green, brown, orange) and 456 pages. It featured a frontispiece engraving by Stephen Alonzo Schoff from a portrait by Charles Hine, depicting Whitman as a genteel romantic. It contained 146 new poems and no preface. Previously published poems were revised and titled, and poems overall were presented in thematic groupings or clusters.

Republican Party candidate Abraham Lincoln elected president of the United States to the consternation of Democrats and pro-slavery advocates who viewed the selection as a prelude to disunion.

Thayer and Eldridge declared bankruptcy and lost property control over Whitman’s carefully prepared plates for the 1860 edition of Leaves of Grass. Whitman’s royalties for the edition came to an end.

Saw president-elect Abraham Lincoln for the first time in person, as Lincoln passed through New York on the way to his March inauguration in Washington, D.C. Though initially skeptical of Lincoln, Whitman would in the following years grow to admire him and his presidency greatly.
